page.title: 19TOURISM IN LLANBISTER
page.content: Farm tourism started in the 1960's, giving income to the farmers wives providing Bed and Breakfast. Staying at farms soon became popular with British and overseas visitors found that the friendly, personal attention provided an opportunity to learn about life on a farm. Home produce and Welsh cooking enhances the appeal. A typical breakfast would be cereals or porridge, fruit juice followed by bacon, egg, sausage and tomato with tea to finish. The average charge is Â£7 per night. In 1981 an arts studio was established. Visitors from home and abroad are taught art and textile crafts in the converted stable and are accommodated in a guest house on the same site. Courses taught by the qualified owners last from 2 days to 3 weeks. There is a caravan site in the area for static and touring caravans.
